diversity</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Closing the gap Leadership perspectives on promoting women in financial services","displayName":"Closing the gap Leadership perspectives on promoting women in financial services","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"63fe0b38-6537-4a80-99a6-9a04aa07a836","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":5,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Closing the gap: Leadership perspectives on promoting women in financial services"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Leadership perspectives on promoting women in financial services"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Men still make up most of the management ranks at banks and insurers. New survey data and interviews with female executives point the way to improving gender diversity."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Men and women in financial services begin their careers at parity, but women account for only 19 percent of positions in the C-suite. Our research breaks down the current state of gender diversity in the industry and explores ways to improve the representation of women at every level."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2018-09-06T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhere does the financial-services sector stand\u003c/strong\u003e when it comes to \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/gender-equality\"\u003egender equality\u003c/a\u003e? To answer the question, this article looks at the experiences of financial-services employees in North America, gathers insights from female senior leaders (those who have reached the level of vice president or above), and reviews best-practice policies and programs to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/delivering-through-diversity\"\u003epromote diversity\u003c/a\u003e and inclusion.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn North America, women account for over half of the entry-level workforce in financial services. They have reached the highest levels within companies, and their numbers at the top continue to grow, albeit slowly. Despite this progress, women still represent fewer than one in five positions in the financial-services C-suite. There is much work to be done to achieve \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/ten-things-to-know-about-gender-equality\"\u003egender parity\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the financial-services sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research for \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b2cc8bf50-5b5a-44d6-92dc-9330f203c8aa%7d%40en\"\u003eWomen in the Workplace\u003c/a\u003e, a collaborative initiative between LeanIn.Org and McKinsey, examines the gender-parity gap in financial services and looks at what can be done to close it. As part of Women in the Workplace\u0026rsquo;s effort to create the definitive fact base on women\u0026rsquo;s advancement in leadership, we surveyed more than 14,000 employees at 39 financial-services companies[[footnote 1]] and interviewed 12 female senior executives at financial-services companies in North America. Although the data are based on North American research, we believe the insights and implications have global relevance.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar numbers]]\n\u003cp\u003eMore than 90 percent of financial-services companies surveyed assert a commitment to gender diversity. This commitment makes clear business sense: companies with greater gender diversity perform better. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s research has shown that companies in the top quartile for gender diversity on executive teams were 21 percent more likely to outperform on profitability and 27 percent more likely to demonstrate superior value creation[[footnote 2]]  (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Gender parity by the numbers\u0026rdquo;).  Furthermore, companies in the top quartile for ethnic/cultural diversity on executive teams were 33 percent more likely to have industry-leading profitability.[[footnote 3]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImproved representation of female leaders will lead to a more rounded view of customers. This is particularly critical in financial services, given that more than half of women now control their household finances and are responsible for household savings and investing.[[footnote 4]]  Furthermore, companies that do not focus on gender diversity will find themselves at a disadvantage in the war for talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n[[Image A]]\n\u003cp\u003eGiven a strong business case for change, much more work needs to be done. Our research breaks down the current state of gender diversity in the financial-services industry to consider the impact by subsector, employment level, and race. We also explore employee experiences in the workplace to understand better the root causes of today\u0026rsquo;s challenges. The gender-parity issues facing the financial-services industry are complex, but there are ways to address these challenges to improve the representation of women at every level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eGender diversity in today\u0026rsquo;s financial-services industry\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar women]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo build a definitive fact base on women\u0026rsquo;s advancement in leadership, we leveraged insights gathered from financial-services companies in the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/gender-equality/still-looking-for-room-at-the-top-ten-years-of-research-on-women-in-the-workplace\"\u003eWomen in the Workplace\u003c/a\u003e Survey. These companies represent three subsectors in North America: banking and consumer finance, asset management and wholesale banking, and insurance.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research shows that women remain significantly underrepresented in the upper levels of financial-services companies. Women and men in financial services begin their careers at parity, making up roughly equal portions of entry-level staff, but higher up the ladder, women account for only 19 percent of positions in the C-suite (Exhibit 1). This is slightly lower than the 22 percent average for US women overall.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe lower representation of women does not appear to be driven by attrition; in fact, company-level attrition among females is either equal to or lower than attrition among males for every financial-services role, except for the most senior positions. And yet, as they advance through their careers, women steadily lose ground to their male peers at every stage. The biggest drop occurs early in their tenure, when women are 24 percent less likely to attain their first promotion than their male peers, even though they request promotions at similar rates (Exhibit 2). Women of color are particularly disadvantaged: they are 34 percent less likely to make their first promotion than men in financial services (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;For women of color: An even steeper path to leadership\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eCareer perspectives\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe have taken a deeper look into women\u0026rsquo;s perspectives at both entry and senior-management levels to uncover why female representation declines at each stage. Our interviews with leading female financial-services executives point to factors that enable women to succeed and advance, and they suggest actions financial-services companies can take to advance gender diversity.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image B]]\n\u003ch3\u003eA slow start: Barriers for entry-level women in financial services\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe experiences of entry-level women in financial services help to explain the steep drop-off in female representation between entry-level and middle-management roles. Most notably, many women early in their careers do not aspire to top positions, and even when they do, they often lack the support needed to rise to the top.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAn ambition gap\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWomen in entry-level roles in financial services seldom envision themselves in a top executive position; only 26 percent aim for this goal, as compared with 40 percent of their male peers and 31 percent of entry-level women across all industries. Entry-level women in financial services cite a lack of interest in such roles, concerns about balancing family and work commitments, the perceived pressure associated with the top jobs, and too much politics as the primary reasons the leadership career path is less appealing (Exhibit 3). While entry-level men share some of these concerns, they are significantly less likely to express concern over the pressure of the job. This difference might be explained in part by real differences in the experiences male and female leaders report having in the workplace.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eA limited number of female role models in leadership positions might also limit women\u0026rsquo;s motivation to make it to the top. \u0026ldquo;The lack of women in C-suite positions is a self-perpetuating cycle,\u0026rdquo; says Deanna Strable, executive vice president and CFO at Principal Financial Services. \u0026ldquo;Because we don\u0026rsquo;t have many females in the C-suite, young women don\u0026rsquo;t see role models or potential paths towards executive-level leadership and are more likely to deselect themselves out of higher-level leadership roles.\u0026rdquo; Marianne Lake, CFO of JPMorgan Chase, believes that having more women at all senior-executive levels is important to inspire entry-level women to aim higher. \u0026ldquo;I think women are looking at the industry, the board, the C-suite, and management to find people who are similar to them so that they understand they can also succeed in those roles,\u0026rdquo; she observes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, entry-level women are more likely than men to express concern about failure on the job. This might result from a confidence gap but could also reflect a real difference in the impact of failure for men and women. Of entry-level women, 57 percent say that fear of a high-profile failure would affect their day-to-day experience as a top executive, compared with just 42 percent of their male peers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLower ambition in entry-level roles is not the sole reason for women\u0026rsquo;s lower representation in the C-suite. Most of the senior-level women interviewed for this article were driven to succeed but say that they never consciously aspired to reach the uppermost levels of leadership. Rather, they simply worked hard to do their best at every stage in their careers and maintained a strong sense of their value to their companies. Marianne Lake, for example, says that she has \u0026ldquo;always been ambitious, but in the sense that I\u0026rsquo;ve always wanted to be the best that I can be at whatever I\u0026rsquo;m doing at the time.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKathleen Murphy, president of personal investing at Fidelity, says that she simply realized one day that she had what it took to take on an executive role. \u0026ldquo;I went from being the general counsel and chief compliance officer to the chief administrative officer, with all the various staff functions reporting to me, and spending a lot of time with the CEO. I\u0026rsquo;m looking around the table and thinking, \u0026lsquo;I can do this too,\u0026rsquo;\u0026rdquo; she explains.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInadequate access to sponsorship\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor entry-level women, lack of support and sponsorship is an additional barrier to advancement. The 2017 Women in the Workplace research showed that women who receive advice from managers and senior leaders on career advancement are more likely to be promoted,[[footnote 6]] and yet earlier-tenure women receive less encouragement and support from managers and senior leaders in advancing their careers than do their male peers. Such encouragement and support can make all the difference, as Karen Peetz, retired president of the Bank of New York Mellon, relates: \u0026ldquo;There are inevitable ups and downs [during a career], and the downs get magnified. Often women and minorities give up during that down time, partly because they don\u0026rsquo;t have the support infrastructure that tells them to keep going, because it will get better.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFurthermore, entry-level women are less likely than men to have managers who act as their advocates and help them identify opportunities to pursue. Nor do they receive senior leaders\u0026rsquo; advice on advancement or navigating organizational politics as frequently as do men (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eC\u0026eacute;line Duf\u0026eacute;tel, CFO at T. Rowe Price, suggests that women might have difficulty finding sponsors because male leaders might feel that they have less in common with their female colleagues. \u0026ldquo;Throughout the course of my career, I\u0026rsquo;ve found it at times lonely and exhausting to stand out so much. I think it can be hard for colleagues to relate to you, and they\u0026rsquo;re sometimes uncomfortable giving you feedback or mentorship. They\u0026rsquo;re not as comfortable going to dinner or having a drink with you, and you miss out on those valuable personal interactions,\u0026rdquo; she says.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, entry-level women might not insist on such support, because they do not yet recognize the importance of cultivating a strong network of supporters and advocates. Whereas senior-level women come to view sponsorship as the factor most essential to success, entry-level women believe that performance is the strongest driver of advancement. They tend to view strong communication skills, being an effective team player, and delivering exceptional results as the most important factors of success (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis failure to recognize the significance of sponsorship is exacerbated by the fact that the vast majority\u0026mdash;81 percent\u0026mdash;of entry-level women in financial services cultivate networks that are largely female or evenly split between males and females. In contrast, 94 percent of entry-level men cultivate networks that are largely male or evenly split between males and females. The fact that entry-level women skew toward women in their networks can affect their opportunities down the line. As these women progress through their careers, their networks will have fewer and fewer women who can serve as sponsors, since the upper levels of corporate management are predominantly male.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eView from the top: Secrets to success from female senior executives\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe female financial-services executives we interviewed have successfully navigated many of the challenges previously described. They are passionate about the advancement of women in the field, and their perspectives provide insight into how entry-level women can move up the ladder. The interviewees consistently highlighted three fundamental building blocks of success for women in financial services: finding sponsorship, taking risks, and knowing and communicating one\u0026rsquo;s value.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuild a strong network of sponsors\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[Image C]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe female senior executives we interviewed consistently cited sponsorship as a critical success factor. This view was reinforced by our data and is unique to senior-level women in financial services, as compared with their male peers, younger counterparts, and senior-level women in other fields. Senior-level women in financial services are also more likely to see \u0026ldquo;political savvy\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;that is, knowing how to navigate office politics\u0026mdash;as an important driver of success than their male peers.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 4]]\n[[PullQuote 5]]\n[[PullQuote 6]]\n\u003ch3\u003eTake risks early and often\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe senior-level women we interviewed encouraged younger women to take risks early in their careers. These risks can involve trying out different business units, roles, locations, and even industries to build a broad foundation of experiences that will serve them in future leadership roles.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 7]]\n[[PullQuote 8]]\n[[PullQuote 9]]\n[[PullQuote 10]]\n\u003ch3\u003eKnow and communicate your value\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral interviewees credited their success to hard work and a strong sense of confidence in their individual value to their employer or business. Many emphasized the importance of communicating their worth and accomplishments to those who matter.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 11]]\n[[PullQuote 12]]\n[[PullQuote 13]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHeadwinds at the top: Ongoing challenges for senior-level women in financial services\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven women who reach the most senior levels often look back and conclude that their gender has hindered their advancement. Over half of the senior-level women\u0026mdash;those who have reached the level of vice president or above\u0026mdash;surveyed believe that they have missed out on opportunities because of their gender, compared with just 10 percent of their male peers. This inequity continues for several reasons.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image D]]\n\u003ch3\u003eAccess to senior leadership remains uneven\u0026mdash;even at the highest levels\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the value they place on sponsorship, senior-level women are still less likely than their male peers to receive substantial support from senior management, even though they ask for it at the same rate that men do. Just 34 percent of senior-level women in financial services say they have received advice on career advancement from a manager or senior leader, while 44 percent of their male peers say they have.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe interviewees who cited sponsorship as a major success factor tended to find their sponsors naturally, without consciously seeking them out. For example, Beverly Anderson, head of cards and retail services at Wells Fargo, found many of her sponsors through working relationships. She explains, \u0026ldquo;I\u0026rsquo;ve usually found a way to connect to somebody based on the work that I\u0026rsquo;m doing. I try to leverage that connection into a relationship, and then I make sure that I nurture that relationship, because it doesn\u0026rsquo;t come often.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSenior-level women are also less likely to have frequent interaction about work with senior leaders at their company: 41 percent of women have these interactions at least once a month, while 49 percent of their male peers do. This trend in financial services is worse than the overall average, as 49 percent of women across all industries have such interactions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBalancing family and work becomes increasingly challenging\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ambition gap persists even among women at the most senior levels, and the inability to balance family and work is cited by half of senior-level women as a major reason for not wanting to pursue top executive roles. This finding is perhaps not surprising, given the fact that as women\u0026rsquo;s responsibilities at work increase with seniority, they largely maintain their responsibilities at home. Nearly half of senior-level women say that they continue to shoulder most household responsibilities, while just 13 percent of their male peers say the same.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompared to their male peers, senior-level women are also much more likely to believe that prioritizing work\u0026ndash;life balance\u0026mdash;including participating in flexibility programs, such as maternity leave and flexible work schedules\u0026mdash;will undermine their ability to succeed at work. This view is perhaps because they perceive the penalty to be higher as their responsibilities at work increase with seniority. Ultimately, they are less likely than senior-level men to view the benefits of top leadership as being worth the cost (Exhibit 6).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eSome of these women worry that a financial-services career does not structurally lend itself to work\u0026ndash;life balance. Margo Cook, president of Nuveen Advisory Services, comments, \u0026ldquo;Finance careers don\u0026rsquo;t feel friendly to women. Some women are attracted to related industries, like consulting or accounting, where the structure better allows for them to have kids and then reenter the workforce without the sense of falling behind. But the finance industry can do a better job of that. We as an industry must figure out how to keep women through the course of their career.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWomen might also be limited by their colleagues\u0026rsquo; assumptions about their work\u0026ndash;life priorities. Karen Peetz observes, \u0026ldquo;The prejudice that holds women back is the limiting of expectations. It\u0026rsquo;s assuming you don\u0026rsquo;t want to do certain things. I had two kids and was married, so people assumed that I wouldn\u0026rsquo;t want to take an assignment in London, that I wouldn\u0026rsquo;t want to drag them along. That wasn\u0026rsquo;t true. Be vocal about what you want. Don\u0026rsquo;t assume that people will know.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image E]]\n\u003ch2\u003eA road map to gender parity at all career stages\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eToday, with women occupying fewer than one in five roles in the C-suite in financial services, achieving gender parity in the sector seems to be an ambitious goal. Yet, there is a path to get there. Through extensive research and interviews with leaders in the field, we have identified a number of best-practice solutions to address the challenges previously outlined.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRebrand the industry to make it more attractive to women\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDemonstrating that financial services is a sector in which women can thrive is a critical first step to achieving parity. Doing so will help improve female representation at the earlier stages of the career funnel\u0026mdash;and is particularly important in subsectors, such as asset management and wholesale banking, where women start out below parity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to C\u0026eacute;line Duf\u0026eacute;tel, \u0026ldquo;For investments roles, it\u0026rsquo;s an entry-point issue. Very few women seek those careers out of school. I remember when I was interviewing for an internship way back when, the banks felt intimidating to me, which is why I chose consulting. That\u0026rsquo;s why, at my company, we make a concerted effort to attract women\u0026mdash;for example, a stock pitch workshop for first-year women MBAs and partnerships with organizations such as Girls Who Invest.\u0026rdquo; Initiatives of this kind signal that the sector is one that will support and celebrate women. Targeted initiatives can also help address the lower levels of excitement women express about aiming for the top. As some interviewees pointed out, the financial crisis damaged the industry\u0026rsquo;s reputation and made it less appealing to college graduates overall. The industry must make a special effort, then, to rewrite its narrative. Financial-services companies should publicize their efforts to boost gender parity in the workplace and make clear that these efforts are being taken seriously, with visible action.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA rebranding of financial services will require its leaders to commit to change, not only by taking action to make their companies places where women can thrive, but also by voicing their commitment to galvanize the industry at large. As Margo Cook from Nuveen Advisory Services says, \u0026ldquo;Making these issues a standard, let alone accepted, topic for all leaders to talk about\u0026mdash;male or female\u0026mdash;is what will break down the walls.\u0026rdquo; Speaking up for change will propel other companies and the industry overall to move toward greater equity for women.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnhance the quality of and access to sponsorship\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs our data demonstrate, sponsorship matters to women at all career stages. This is especially true in financial services, in which senior-level women are more likely than their entry-level peers and senior-level women in other industries to cite sponsorship as the most important contributor to their success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are concrete steps that financial-services companies can take to ensure that women\u0026mdash;especially women in the earlier stages of their careers\u0026mdash;have more and better access to sponsors. First, they can expand offerings for formal sponsorship programs. At present, less than half of the financial-services companies we surveyed have such programs, and only 58 percent have formal mentorship programs. These programs should be designed specifically to address the challenges that hinder entry-level women from advancement into the senior ranks. Specifically, they should expose entry-level women to female role models in senior positions. \u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s important to expose female leaders to junior folks in the organization, so that junior women can talk to and see role models,\u0026rdquo; Alice Milligan, chief digital client experience officer at Citi\u0026rsquo;s US consumer bank, observes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFurthermore, senior leaders, including men, should be actively involved in promoting sponsorship so that it becomes a company-wide priority. The small number of senior-level women cannot bear this responsibility alone; there simply are not enough of them to address the scale of change required. Leaders and managers should be coached to speak directly about how they navigate the career challenges that entry-level women face so that these women will feel more desire and confidence to strive for top positions. In this same vein, managers need to be prompted to encourage women to take on stretch opportunities\u0026mdash;given the importance of building a r\u0026eacute;sum\u0026eacute; of diverse experiences cited by many of the senior-level women we interviewed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSheri Rhodes, chief technology officer at Western Union, recognizes the importance of senior leaders inspiring their younger colleagues through sponsorship: \u0026ldquo;I\u0026rsquo;ve been fortunate to have had sponsorship\u0026mdash;from both men and women\u0026mdash;throughout my career. I have the responsibility to model that behavior and to be an advocate for change.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile female role models are crucial, both men and women should serve as sponsors and mentors to ensure that women build the diverse networks they need throughout their careers. If sponsorship and networking groups involve only women, Karen Peetz notes, they can \u0026ldquo;unwittingly be viewed as some kind of fringe effort. It\u0026rsquo;s a best practice to have heterogenous groups, with men involved as mentors, coming to programs, and demonstrating their support.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond formal programs, companies should monitor the quality of and access to sponsorship for both junior and senior-level women. For example, a best practice is to send out an annual sponsorship survey to identify sponsors and candidates for sponsorship so that gaps can be identified and addressed early.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEliminate bias in reviews and promotions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/gender-equality/focusing-on-what-works-for-workplace-diversity\"\u003eReducing bias in reviews and promotions\u003c/a\u003e will boost the lagging promotion rate for entry-level women and help alleviate senior-level women\u0026rsquo;s sense that their gender has hindered their advancement. This perception is not misplaced: as previously noted, entry-level women in financial services are 24 percent less likely than their male peers to be promoted, versus 18 percent of women overall.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image F]]\n\u003cp\u003eIt is therefore especially important for the financial-services industry to address the biases\u0026mdash;often unconscious\u0026mdash;that are holding back female talent. While 79 percent of companies in the financial-services sector offer unconscious-bias training, only 18 percent require it. Unconscious-bias training must tackle not only gender but race, sexual orientation, and other areas of bias. This is particularly critical given the double discrimination women of color face. Such training can increase inclusiveness for all people. Effective intervention requires going beyond merely helping individuals recognize bias to providing them with the tools to address bias head on, particularly in high-stakes situations like hiring, performance, and promotion discussions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA commitment to addressing unconscious bias needs to come from the top to be effective. Jenny Johnson, president and COO at Franklin Templeton Investments, confirms, \u0026ldquo;No matter what policies you have, if your senior team doesn\u0026rsquo;t demonstrate that behavior, it won\u0026rsquo;t permeate through the rest of the firm. From the CEO down, we encourage everybody to take unconscious-bias training, and then we track the number of people who do it.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGive employees the flexibility to balance work and family\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur interviews have highlighted the common perception that the financial-services field is less conducive to work\u0026ndash;life balance; in fact, challenges in balancing work and family are the number-one reason senior-level women do not strive to become top executives. To address this, financial-services companies must find ways to offer more flexibility in the workplace. Flexibility programs are common across the financial sector: currently, nearly 90 percent of financial-services companies offer extended maternity and/or paternity leave, and 92 percent offer flexible work policies.  However, our research shows that women\u0026mdash;especially senior-level women\u0026mdash;fear that partaking in flexibility programs might hinder their advancement.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo \u0026ldquo;de-risk\u0026rdquo; flexible policies\u0026mdash;in both perception and reality\u0026mdash;companies must encourage leaders of both genders to signal their acceptance and usage of flexible working policies. Additionally, companies should foster open dialogues about how policies could be enhanced to meet employees\u0026rsquo; and their families\u0026rsquo; needs better.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies should emphasize that these policies are for everyone, not just women. As Kathleen Murphy notes, \u0026ldquo;Flexible policies, such as flexible hours or working virtually, are often important\u0026mdash;and they are gender neutral, really, as they benefit everyone. Both women and men want to have the ability to attend kids\u0026rsquo; events or work flexibly to balance personal obligations.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, as Jenny Johnson remarks, such gender-neutral policies boost employee satisfaction across the board. \u0026ldquo;If companies encourage men to participate in personal activities, both men and women will be happier, because they\u0026rsquo;ll get to engage in those things, and women will feel less stigmatized by participating. It\u0026rsquo;s all about the culture that you create in your firm.\u0026rdquo; Greater participation from men at home also rebalances the increasing workload that senior-level women typically manage as breadwinner and primary caregiver.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuild accountability through target setting and measurement\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCollecting data on gender is an important first step in creating accountability for advancing gender diversity. Ninety-five percent of financial-services companies track gender representation across all levels, and 71 percent measure the gender representation of their promotion candidates. However, far fewer financial-services companies have clearly defined what they are striving toward. Thirty-four percent set targets for gender representation at senior levels and 29 percent for more junior roles. And only 11 percent of financial-services companies set targets for gender representation in promotions, which is lower than the 18 percent figure for companies overall\u0026mdash;another factor that likely contributes to the lower promotion rates for women.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinancial-services companies could push further by consistently setting targets for female representation and promotion rates and by holding leaders accountable for meeting them. A quantitative approach will likely resonate with individuals in a numbers-driven financial-services industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the Bank of New York Mellon, Karen Peetz found diversity targets to be highly effective. \u0026ldquo;One powerful thing that our company did was to have HR share stats with leaders about diversity at all organizational levels. We didn\u0026rsquo;t have quotas, but we had targets for increasing diversity, year over year, that were part of our executive-committee compensations. I\u0026rsquo;m expected to move the needle every year on having more women and more diverse people on my team. It\u0026rsquo;s measured, and I get a grade,\u0026rdquo; she explains.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJacqueline Molnar at Western Union also sees the importance of setting targets and holding leaders accountable. \u0026ldquo;It has to be a target, a KPI [key performance indicator] that\u0026rsquo;s measurable, with metrics against it. Are your slates diverse? Are your interviewees and interviewers diverse? Hold executives accountable, and then reward and impose consequences on leaders who consistently fail to institute those policies and procedures.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe path to parity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe goal to achieve parity in financial services is ambitious. However, our interviews with female senior executives and deep research demonstrate there is indeed a road to the top and clear steps that can be taken to pave the way for more women to get there.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image G]]\n\u003cp\u003eMoving toward gender parity at the top will require corporate leaders\u0026mdash;both male and female\u0026mdash;to view gender equality as a strategic priority and one that is integrated into the organization\u0026rsquo;s day-to-day work. As Marianne Lake observes, \u0026ldquo;If we believe that investing in women is critical to the company\u0026rsquo;s success, we have to think about it constantly. It\u0026rsquo;s one dimension of running a successful business. We can have targets around gender diversity\u0026mdash;and we should measure them\u0026mdash;but making it a priority comes down to leadership and culture.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeverly Anderson echoes this sentiment and believes that change will come when diversity becomes a universal objective: \u0026ldquo;The customer base has to demand diversity. The shareholders\u0026mdash;everybody\u0026mdash;have to decide that this is important. We all talk an interesting game around diversity, particularly gender, but without full support, it just doesn\u0026rsquo;t translate into the senior levels,\u0026rdquo; she says.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe investment and commitment yields dividends in terms of talent, performance, and values. And the urgency to accelerate gender diversity in financial services is increasing as the customer base becomes increasingly diverse. Many believe the competitive marketplace ultimately will demand diversity from financial-services providers, especially as women increasingly take the financial reins of their households. According to Margo Cook, \u0026ldquo;What will drive change in our industry is the amount of wealth that will continue to transition to women over the next several years as baby boomers age. More women will control assets because of their longer life spans. We can\u0026rsquo;t stay, let alone thrive, in the business if we\u0026rsquo;re not shifting how we talk to women. It\u0026rsquo;s a business case: financial-services companies need to change their organization\u0026rsquo;s landscape to attract and retain their clients\u0026rsquo; wealth.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuccess will require unwavering commitment from all leaders in financial services to move toward parity. As Marianne Lake concludes, \u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s about blocking and tackling. There\u0026rsquo;s no silver bullet; this is going to be a long game.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp full-width]]"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2018-09-06T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCombined, the 39 financial-services companies employ approximately 1.2 million people; Having had that sponsorship, particularly by a man, was profound for me.\r\n\r\n"},"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"center"},"value":{"value":"center-align"}}},"citation":{"value":"Jacqueline Molnar, Western Union"},"enableQuotes":{"boolValue":true},"CTA":{"url":"","linkType":"internal","text":"","target":"","className":"","queryString":"","anchor":"","targetItem":null}},{"description":{"value":"Im a huge proponent of sponsorship. I can track the times when my career accelerated due to male sponsorshipmostly white male sponsorshipearly in my career. I happened to meet the gentleman who was the head of corporate banking early in my career. He stayed with me as I moved through my career, and that made a huge difference. Taking small risks has enabled me to hone my judgment and gave me the experience to take larger risks.\r\n\r\n"},"mediaID":{"value":"8"},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"center"},"value":{"value":"center-align"}}},"citation":{"value":"Ranjana Clark, MUFG Union Bank, N.A."},"enableQuotes":{"boolValue":true},"CTA":{"url":"","linkType":"internal","text":"","target":"","className":"","queryString":"","anchor":"","targetItem":null}},{"description":{"value":"In general, men seem to have more confidence in their ability to get to the next level, to take the next risk. Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"women"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIn the financial-services industry, women of color represent one in five employees at entry levels, but they virtually disappear from representation at higher levels. Across the 39 financial-services companies we surveyed, there are only ten women of color in C-suite roles today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne factor is lower promotion rates: at nearly every step in the pipeline, women of color in financial services are promoted at lower rates than both men and white women. Attrition rates for women of color are also higher than those for white women in entry-level and middle-management roles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese trends are especially troubling considering that more women of color than their white female peers express an ambition to make it to the top. Of entry-level women of color, 36 percent desire to become a senior executive\u0026mdash;a proportion nearing that of their male peers\u0026mdash;versus 22 percent of white women.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWomen of color face unique challenges and often feel that they are held to a higher standard. Senior-level women of color are more likely to view any failure, big or small, as having jeopardized their success. Moreover, they are more likely to view \u0026ldquo;playing the game\u0026rdquo; and being well liked as critical to success (exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit challenges]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs a woman of color, Beverly Anderson, head of cards and retail services at Wells Fargo, observes that women of color often enter financial careers at an inherent disadvantage. Facing compounded bias due to both their race and their gender, they must work doubly hard to prove themselves. \u0026ldquo;You come in on probation at a deficit and needing to prove your worth more than your counterparts versus coming in with support and the belief that there\u0026rsquo;s a reason you\u0026rsquo;re at the table. If you can stand with confidence and believe in your abilities, you earn your way out of the deficit, so to speak. It\u0026rsquo;s a very tight range at which you have to figure out the game, how to play it, and how to deliver,\u0026rdquo; she notes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSponsorship is one way to address some of these challenges. When reflecting on their careers, senior-level women of color in financial services are much more likely than white women (55 percent versus 44 percent, respectively) to cite a manager or leader as critical to achieving their promotion. Yet, across all industries, women of color\u0026mdash;in particular, black and Latina women\u0026mdash;receive lower levels of support from managers.[[FootNote
